turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: Well, now, where's everyone run off to? Frank?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Downstairs.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: I'm tired.  Really.  I should get home.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: It went well tonight.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Frank works hard.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: And you don't?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He leads, I follow.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: Is that the way it is?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Pretty much.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: He mentioned you had a girl for a while.  A singer.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: For a while.  She left.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: Yes, well, it's probably best. No sense bringing someone else in.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I suppose.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: You miss him, don't you?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It's been a long time, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS.  BAKER
turns.text: Yes.  I supposed you still have that old phone booth.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Hey, he's not sore, is he?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He'll come around.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You never sang before?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Not for money. With my mother.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Fucking.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Look, they were all on their third Mai Tais by the time I got out there anyway.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The Park?  It's only two nights. Why throw away a night?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Because Blackie Carson books the Park and whenever we've needed a gig he's come through.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh.  Well, for Blackie then.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Where's egghead?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: His kid's sick.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I don't know.  It's hard figuring you two as brothers.  Seems like the hospital might've scrambled the babies somewhere.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He takes after our mother.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah,well, a11 I know is mother nature must be one crazy dame.  Shit.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Uh-uh.  I never touch American cigarettes.  What's tomorrow again?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: The Stratford.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Nice place.  Fulla velvet.  Even the bedspreads.  Damn!  Two-fifty a pack and I go through 'em like toothpicks. Twelve-and-a-half cents a piece, you believe that?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Paris Opals.  Twelve-and-a-half cents.  I sat down with a pencil and added it one day.  But I figure, if you're gonna be sticking something in your mouth, you might as well make it the best.  Ah, here's a lost soul.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Mmm.  Like kissing a rose.  Well, au revoir.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Hey.  You feel like a cup of coffee?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You kidding?  We must've killed three pots in there.  Anyway, I gotta get home.  Rest the pipes.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You want me to walk you?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: No. Thanks. She starts to move away, then stops and looks back.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Hey, listen.  You're not going soft on me, are you? I mean, you're not gonna start dreaming about me and waking up all sweaty and looking at me like I'm some kinda princess when I burp.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: I mean, that'd be too creepy. With us working together and all.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Forget it.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Nothing personal --

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: He do that every year?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Every year.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Aren't the kids asleep?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Every year.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: So why's he do it?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I guess in case one year they're not.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh, sorry.  With the light always on, it's hard to tell.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It's okay.  Last one.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Can't sleep?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: In and out.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: It's the waves.  God's music, my mother used to say. She was crazy for the ocean.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah, well, I wish God would go a little easy on the trumpets.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: How's egghead?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Like a baby. You?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: In and out.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: If you want, I got a pack in the room.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No thanks.  I never touch French cigarettes.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, thanks for sticking your head in.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Hey, business is business.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: It wasn't business.  It was pleasure.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Just dinner and dance, right?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Relax.  We'll drop the song.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Guess I got a little scattered.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It's a shitty  song.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: How do you do it? Every night?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Practice.  There are worse songs, you know. Not many, but a few.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I can keep the beat.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Better than that.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: What's the matter?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: What'd I say?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You're upset.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm not upset.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: All I said was you were good.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Look. You don't know good. All right?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: What's that supposed to mean?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It means you wouldn't know good if it came up and fucked you.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You were good.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Let's make a deal.  You shut up.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You were good.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Because I saw the other people! And they knew you were good! You were good, goddamnit!

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Nina?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Who's Nina?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Friend.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Friend?  What's she look like? Maybe I can help you find her.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: She's four feet tall.  Ed?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Ed? How many people live here?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I have to make him some chili. Okay?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Like diamonds, huh?  I never get over it. When I was a little girl, my mama'd stand me before the window and tell me to close my eyes and make a wish.Like I could reach out and grab all the lights of the city and string them into-a necklace for myself.  She'd take my hand and when she closed her eyes, I don't know, it was like she really believed it.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How come you didn't close your eyes?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You know, I saw you guys once. You and Frank.  At the Roosevelt.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Must've been a cheap date.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Soap convention.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Soap?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah, they got a convention for everything. At least he was clean.  Boy, the guys I met when I was with the service, you wouldn't believe.  The older ones, they were okay.  Nice.  Polite.  Pulled the chair out for you.  But the younger ones ...  Mama used to say, dance with a man once, but if you can feel calluses on his fingers, don't dance with him again.  She thought she had it all figured out. But she wasn't so smart.  There are killers with palms like a baby.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: History.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: My father proposed to my mother in there.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: No kidding?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: The both of them?  In there?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He called her.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh. So what's it doing here?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Long story.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You sending me home?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: They'd been out dancing all night and he took her to the train station -- she lived over in Brookhaven.  Usually held ride with her, but this time he didn't.  Anyway, he starts walking home, only as he's walking he starts getting nervous.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Nervous?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: By the time he gets to the corner newstand, he's got her meeting some rich guy on the train, the rich guy's asked her to marry him, and he's reading about it in the morning edition.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You're kidding.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He had a mind that escalated things.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: So, what happened?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He calls her, asks her to marry him, she thinks he's crazy, he asks her again, she still thinks he's crazy but says yes anyway, and the next thing you know he's got his brothers down there and they're tearing the thing right off the curb.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe he thought some rich guy was gonna try and call her.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Wow.  But I still don't see how ...

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ma didn't want it around.  After.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Frank said ---

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Frank wasn't 'there.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh. Hi.  Sorry.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Coffee?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah... No.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Look, if you want to leave...

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah, maybe ... No. God, I hate these cigarettes!

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Shit.  I think I started a fire.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: If our feet get hot, you grab the piano.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: You can always get another girl.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: There's always another girl.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Saw the sign outside.  Got your own sign, huh?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.  Got my own sign.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: We outgrew each other.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah, well, like I said, it didn't figure.  You two.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: You don't pick your brother.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: So how's the cat food business?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Terrific.  I'm doing vegetables next week.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What kind?

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Huh?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Vegetables.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Oh. Carrots.  And peas.  None of the important ones.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Listen... you want to get a drink?  I got a new place.  Or we could go to a bar ...  Well, maybe not a bar.  But I know a place uptown, if you want --

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I've given it up.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Tell egghead I said hi.  If you see him.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: If I see him.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Jack.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Hi.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Well, this is some surprise.  Hey ... You don't look so good, pal.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Let me get the light.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Sneak out in the morning.  Before the guy could wake up and ruin it.  Never figured I'd be on the other end of it, though.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I didn't want to wake you.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Thanks.  For letting me in last night.

turns.speaker: SUSIE
turns.text: Funny how life repeats itself, huh?  Over and over. Like a song.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Ah, you know. Howsa pooch?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Losing his teeth.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: No shit. It's the goddamn water. Kill an ox. I buy bottled for my Danny. You can't trust the taps.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah.  Jesus, you look like fucking royalty, Tommy.

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Yeah.  The big boys sent it down yesterday.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Another five years, huh?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: Like clockwork.  You got a good memory, Jackie.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: It ain't always a blessing.  My brother here?

turns.speaker: TOMMY
turns.text: He's got blood in his eye.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Did you break a cup, Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Eddie did.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Guess they're up.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Sounds big.  What's he do?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Process server. Ma said it's like a lawyer only the hours are more regular.  All I know's he came to take the TV one afternoon and ended up staying for dinner.  And breakfast.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: What happened to the donut king?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Married.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: In the old days, every man had a shaving mug that he kept at the barber shop.  Then, whenever he wanted a shave, held go down to the barber shop and there would be his mug, waiting for him.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Is that what you used to do?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: My days are not the old days, genius.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: What are they?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: The recent past.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Oh.  Bigfoot gets his out of a can.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: How do you know?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: I saw his stuff in the bathroom.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: I guess it's getting serious.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Maybe he'll ask your ma to marry him.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: I hope not.  He's already busted the springs in two chairs.  Hey, what's this?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ivory.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Looks old.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Older than me.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Wow.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Hey, what do you want to do?  Grow a beard?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Well, let's get your first prom under the belt, okay?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: What's a prom?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Ever go to church?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: I tried Cheerios this morning. He didn't even get up. Maybe they took out the wrong teeth.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He's just feeling sorry for himself.  This is it, pal.  Hear me? Two bucks a can.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: How'd the show go?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Okay.  How'd yours go?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Not so good.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: From Hurley's?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Eighty proof. What d'ya say? Think you can handle it?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Jack.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Can I stay here tonight?  Even if she comes here?

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: Merry Christmas, Jack.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Merry Christmas.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: There were more flowers last year.  Mr. Rinaldi down at the drugstore says it's going to snow by New Year's.  Says he can feel it in his elbows. I hope it snows.  I want to make a snowman. You ever make a snowman, Jack?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: NINA
turns.text: That's what I want to do. I want to make a snowman.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: John.  It's good to see you.

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Good to see you, Ma.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: So. How are you?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Fine.  You?

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Oh, fine.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Big piece or little?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Huh? Oh, no.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: None?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: I'm not much for sweets.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: How's that dog of yours?  What was his name?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: Eddie.

turns.speaker: MRS. BAKER
turns.text: Yes.  Right.  Eddie.  How is he?

turns.speaker: JACK
turns.text: He's losing his teeth.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Waxy Wright.  Didn't Jon Archer bust you for poisoning five members of the Canadian parliament?

turns.speaker: WAXY
turns.text: They never should've voted against U.S. statehood -- the scumbags.  We heard you got wasted.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Do I look wasted -- asshole?

turns.speaker: WAXY
turns.text: You look great, Castor. Really.  Here -- I got a shot of your favorite -- Mescal.  Even has the worm.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Don't they ever let us take these boots off?

turns.speaker: WAXY
turns.text: Not unless you're sent to the "Clinic."

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: You mean if I get sick?

turns.speaker: WAXY
turns.text: They don't give two fucks about your health.  The Clinic's where they send the real hard-cases for attitude adjustment.  Look at O'Neill --

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: What did he do?

turns.speaker: WAXY
turns.text: He hit a guard.

turns.speaker: LAZARRO
turns.text: Fine work, Jon.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Yeah, real fine.  Especially all the casualties.

turns.speaker: LAZARRO
turns.text: I'm complimenting you. Can't you ever just say "thanks"?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: ... Thanks.

turns.speaker: LAZARRO
turns.text: Try to kiss my butt just once before I'm transferred.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Sorry, Admiral.  It wasn't mentioned in the job description.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: He's lying.

turns.speaker: LAZARRO
turns.text: Jon, he's hooked up to a full-spectrum polygraph. No one has ever beaten --

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I don't care -- he's manipulating it.  That bomb has been built and it's out there, somewhere.

turns.speaker: LAZARRO
turns.text: What do you expect us to do -- shut down the city, evacuate two million people on a hunch?

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Uh-oh, somebody's in trouble.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Yeah -- me.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Jesus Christ, Castor.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Drive.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: The last time I took orders from you I ended up with five years probation.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Where am I?

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: My place.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: You shouldn't have brought me here ... it's dangerous.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Better than you bleeding all over my car upholstery. Trust me, Caz, you won't be here long.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I hear you're a manicurist now -- got your own business and everything.  I'm glad you've stayed clean.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Like I had a choice with that anal-retentive Jon Archer rising my ass at the probation hearing.  At least he took an interest. You took off without leaving so much as a Post-it.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I'm not the same person you remember.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Perfect fit.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Should be.  It's yours.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Nice-looking kid.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Of course he is ...  -- He's yours too.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Go on, Adam ...  I'm not asking you for anything -- I was never even going to tell you. But hell, I never thought I'd see you again, either.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: How old is he?

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: Five.  No one knows you're his father.  I thought someone might want to hurt him -- just to hurt you.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Yes ... someone might want to tear him apart -- snuff him out -- for revenge.

turns.speaker: SASHA
turns.text: You're not holding him right ... Caz ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: And this thing can grow it?

turns.speaker: DIETRICH
turns.text: Yes.  Pollux bought one along with the original batch.  Obviously, he found a way to make more.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Why would he need more?

turns.speaker: DIETRICH
turns.text: He's your brother, you figure it out.  Maybe he made another bomb.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Or reactivated the first one.

turns.speaker: DIETRICH
turns.text: Right ... like Jon Archer would ever let that happen.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Hey, bro ...

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: You're not my brother.  The brother I knew would never have been caught by that dumb fuck Archer.  At least tell me the bomb is still going off.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: They haven't found it yet -- Listen, Pollux ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Pollux ...

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: Shut up.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: So?  The procnias averano is a South American bird.  The flight here was only three hours!  And yesterday a European swallow flew by! Where the fuck are we?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: You shoot hoops like a chick, you smoke like a wuss, and -- I don't know -- you're different.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I was in a coma, Pollux. I still feel like shit.

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: Let me have a look.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Do you know what it is to be in a coma?  It fucks up everything -- including your memory! I can't even tell you why Dobbs jumped me yesterday!

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: You porked his wife the day he was arrested.  How could you forget that?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I don't know.  Everything's jumbled -- so you're going to have to help me fill in a few blanks.

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: A few blanks?  Like what?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Like ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Oh, God -- Mom OD'd at County General.

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: Retching and convulsing while those bastards didn't even try to save her sorry ass.  You gave her mouth to mouth -- man -- even then you had some constitution.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Uh -- to kill the doctors?

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: After that.  You promised you'd always take care of me.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: And I bet I've kept that promise ...

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: Only one you've never broken.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: That's not the worst part.

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: What's worse than losing five million bucks?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Being stuck in this rat-hole when it blows.  Bro, what you built was a work of art. That little fucker belongs in the Smithsonian.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Thanks, Pollux.

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: For what?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: For being one helluva guy.

turns.speaker: POLLUX
turns.text: "Thanks?"  I guess they really did fuck you up.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Well, you tried.  You failed miserably, but you tried.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Everything I say is wrong. I can't talk to her anymore.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: She's only 12.  Some day she'll understand that apathy and absence are just special ways of saying "I love you."

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Is that what you think?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Jon ... we just remember how it used to be.  You staying for a while or is this just a piss-stop?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: We need to talk.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I'm late for surgery.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: It's important.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: So is finishing my residency and passing my boards ...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: ... I was dreaming ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Something good?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: We were back in high school. You wanted to join the sky diving team, but I wouldn't let you.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Must've been after we got engaged.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Actually -- in this dream -- I was your mother.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: So you had a nightmare.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Totally -- you were being very, very bad.  You went up in the plane and jumped out.  You had a parachute, but it didn't open.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Were you there to catch me?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: How come?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't know ...  Maybe because you've never needed my help.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Five years ... I still can't get it out of my head -- an inch to the left, Matty would still be alive.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: And you wouldn't be.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What are you saying?  Oh, God -- you're going on assignment again ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: One last time.  It's important ...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You said you'd be here! You promised me -- you promised Jamie!  What could be more important than that?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I can't tell you ... except only I can do it.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: You want me to tell you it's okay to leave?  Okay, go on!  GO!

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Is someone there?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Eve, listen carefully.  The man you think is your husband -- isn't.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Who is this?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Never mind that!  Just take Jamie and get out of that house.  Don't tell anyone where you're going -- especially not him -- just GO.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Okay, you're having an emotional crisis.  You need to seek the help of a trained --

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Think about it, Eve! Everything he's done recently has been peculiar, right?  He's said and done things your husband would never do ...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Whoever you are, don't call again.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Don't hang up ...

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I know you -- you're the one who called.  You're Castor Troy.  You killed my son --

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: -- I called, but I'm not Castor.  I'm your husband.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: How did he expect to do that?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: An NSA surgeon gave me Castor's face.  He handled the transplant, the vocal implant, everything.  But somehow Castor came out of his coma -- and killed everyone who knew about the mission. But not before he was transformed into me.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I took it from my fake husband.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Why point it at me?  I'm the real thing.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I don't know that.  Maybe Jon's already dead.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: What more proof do you need?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Tell me what happened on April 9th -- 13 years ago.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Christ, Jon!  How could you do this to yourself? How could you do this to us?  Do you know -- do you know what he did to me ...?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Whatever happened, whatever he did -- I know it's my fault and I know I can never make it up to you --

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: He freaked out when he thought I had seen this stuff.  I think it's a list of cities -- Santiago, Ho Chi Minh City, Nandi ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Our Pacific Rim stations. These numbers must be bounties. Castor's not wasting any time.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: He's going to kill off our bureau chiefs -- one-by-one.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: -- Or maybe all at once.  There's a get-together tonight at New St. Marks. For all the bureau chiefs and their families.  He's insisted Jamie and I be there too.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: You can't go.  You can't be anywhere near that place.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Jon, what is it?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: The bomb.  He's reactivated it.  And everyone there is going to die.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Can't we call someone? Admiral Lazarro?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: I know Lazarro -- the first person she'd call is "me." We can't take the chance of tipping Castor off.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Jon, if I'm not there, he will be tipped off.  I'll get rid of Jamie -- but you and I are in this together.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Eve ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: How is he?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: No life signs at all. He's a turnip.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: That's what they always say.

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: I started wondering -- if you couldn't switch back -- would it make a difference?

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Would it?

turns.speaker: EVE
turns.text: Damn right.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: How's Loomis?

turns.speaker: TITO
turns.text: Apparently, fine.  He's coming into work.  That's the good news ...

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Go on.

turns.speaker: TITO
turns.text: Castor's still alive --  Technically.  He's a turnip, on total life-support ...

turns.speaker: TITO
turns.text: We can send in a plant -- try to get Pollux to spill the location.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: He'd see that a mile away.  The only person he'd talk to about that bomb is his brother.  Unfortunately, turnips can't talk.

turns.speaker: ARCHER
turns.text: Which ear was it?

turns.speaker: TITO
turns.text: The left, I think.  Those surgeons in Witness Protection can fix things nobody's even broken yet.
